explanations.summary: During urination, the internal urethral sphincter relaxes via decreased sympathetic tone, while the external sphincter relaxes under voluntary control.

whyCorrect.c: The internal urethral sphincter is controlled by sympathetic innervation. During micturition, sympathetic tone decreases, allowing the smooth muscle sphincter to relax.
whyCorrect.d: The external urethral sphincter is skeletal muscle under voluntary (somatic) control via the pudendal nerve. Voluntary relaxation initiates urination.

whyIncorrect.a: Parasympathetic activity INCREASES during urination (detrusor contraction), not decreases. Also, the external sphincter is not controlled by parasympathetic nerves.
whyIncorrect.b: The internal sphincter is smooth muscle controlled by the autonomic nervous system - it cannot be voluntarily relaxed. It relaxes due to decreased sympathetic tone.

explanations.summary: Endothelins, angiotensin II, and ADH (vasopressin) are all vasoconstrictor peptides that raise blood pressure.

whyCorrect.a: Endothelins (especially ET-1) are the most potent known vasoconstrictors, released from endothelial cells and acting on smooth muscle ET-A receptors.
whyCorrect.e: Angiotensin II is a powerful vasoconstrictor peptide that acts on AT1 receptors in vascular smooth muscle.
whyCorrect.f: ADH (vasopressin) causes vasoconstriction via V1 receptors on vascular smooth muscle, in addition to its antidiuretic effects via V2 receptors.

whyIncorrect.b: Adenosine is a vasoDILATOR (not a peptide). It causes vasodilation in most vascular beds, especially coronary and cerebral.
whyIncorrect.c: Kallikrein is an enzyme that produces kinins (bradykinin), which are vasoDILATORS, not vasoconstrictors.
whyIncorrect.d: ANH (atrial natriuretic hormone/peptide) is a vasoDILATOR and promotes natriuresis - it opposes the actions of angiotensin II.

explanations.summary: The thick ascending limb actively reabsorbs NaCl without water, creating the medullary osmotic gradient essential for urine concentration.

whyCorrect.b: The thick ascending limb is IMPERMEABLE to water but actively transports Na+, K+, and Cl- (via NKCC2). This 'single effect' drives the countercurrent multiplier, creating medullary hyperosmolarity.

whyIncorrect.a: Na+ is reabsorbed throughout the nephron: ~65% in proximal tubule, ~25% in loop of Henle, and the rest in distal segments. Not exclusive to thick ascending limb.
whyIncorrect.c: Vasopressin-sensitive water reabsorption occurs in the COLLECTING DUCT (via AQP2 channels), not the thick ascending limb which is impermeable to water.
whyIncorrect.d: Aldosterone acts on the DISTAL TUBULE and COLLECTING DUCT (principal cells), not the thick ascending limb.
whyIncorrect.e: PTH-stimulated Ca2+ reabsorption occurs primarily in the DISTAL CONVOLUTED TUBULE, not the thick ascending limb.

explanations.topicReference: Topic 48: Renal concentration and dilution mechanisms

explanations.summary: Inulin excretion is directly proportional to plasma concentration because inulin is freely filtered and neither reabsorbed nor secreted.

whyCorrect.a: Inulin is the gold standard for GFR measurement because it's freely filtered, not reabsorbed, and not secreted. Excretion = GFR × [plasma inulin], which is a linear relationship.

whyIncorrect.b: Non-linear relationships occur with substances that have saturable transport mechanisms. Inulin has no tubular handling.
whyIncorrect.c: Inversely proportional would mean excretion decreases as plasma concentration increases - the opposite of what happens with inulin.
whyIncorrect.d: Logarithmic relationships don't apply to inulin handling. The relationship is simply linear.
whyIncorrect.e: Transport maximum (Tm) applies to substances with carrier-mediated reabsorption (glucose) or secretion (PAH). Inulin has no tubular transport.

explanations.topicReference: Topic 45: Renal blood flow and GFR

explanations.summary: All glomeruli (including juxtamedullary nephrons) and all proximal tubules are located exclusively in the renal cortex.

whyCorrect.b: ALL glomeruli are located in the cortex, including those of juxtamedullary nephrons. 'Juxtamedullary' refers to their position near the corticomedullary junction, but the glomeruli are still cortical.
whyCorrect.d: Proximal tubules (both convoluted and straight portions) are entirely within the cortex. They never extend into the medulla.

whyIncorrect.a: Vasa recta descend into the MEDULLA alongside the loops of Henle. They are essential for maintaining the medullary osmotic gradient.
whyIncorrect.c: Collecting tubules/ducts traverse BOTH cortex and medulla, extending from cortical collecting ducts down through the medulla to the papillary ducts.
whyIncorrect.e: Loops of Henle extend into the MEDULLA. Juxtamedullary nephrons have long loops that reach deep into the inner medulla.

explanations.topicReference: Topic 45: Renal blood flow and GFR

explanations.summary: Capillary hydrostatic pressure promotes filtration, while interstitial hydrostatic pressure can promote either filtration or absorption depending on its sign.

whyCorrect.c: Intracapillary hydrostatic pressure (Pc) pushes fluid OUT of the capillary into the interstitium - this is the main driving force for filtration.
whyCorrect.d: Interstitial hydrostatic pressure (Pi) is normally slightly negative (-3 mmHg), which promotes filtration. If positive (edema), it would oppose filtration and promote absorption.

whyIncorrect.a: Intracapillary colloid osmotic pressure (plasma oncotic pressure, ~28 mmHg) pulls fluid INTO the capillary - it promotes ABSORPTION, not filtration.
whyIncorrect.b: Interstitial colloid osmotic pressure pulls fluid OUT of capillaries into the interstitium - it promotes FILTRATION, not absorption.

explanations.summary: Cosm = (Uosm × V) / Posm = (100 × 12) / 300 = 4 mL/min. CH2O = V - Cosm = 12 - 4 = 8 mL/min (dilute urine = positive free water clearance).

whyCorrect.a: Osmolar clearance = (Urine osmolarity × Urine flow) / Plasma osmolarity = (100 × 12) / 300 = 1200/300 = 4 mL/min.
whyCorrect.b: Free water clearance = Urine flow - Osmolar clearance = 12 - 4 = 8 mL/min. Positive value indicates the kidney is excreting free water (dilute urine).

whyIncorrect.c: Negative free water clearance (-3 mL/min) would occur with concentrated urine (Uosm > Posm). Here urine is dilute (100 < 300), so CH2O is positive.
whyIncorrect.d: 3 mL/min is incorrect - the calculation gives CH2O = 12 - 4 = 8 mL/min.
whyIncorrect.e: Osmolar clearance is 4 mL/min, not 3 mL/min. Cosm = (100 × 12) / 300 = 4.

explanations.topicReference: Topic 48-49: Renal concentration/dilution and ECF osmolarity

explanations.summary: Local blood flow is primarily regulated by the metabolic activity of the tissue, which produces vasodilator metabolites matching flow to demand.

whyCorrect.e: Metabolic regulation is the dominant mechanism for local blood flow control. Active tissues produce vasodilators (adenosine, CO2, H+, K+, decreased O2) that increase flow proportionally to metabolic need.

whyIncorrect.a: Arteriovenous pressure difference affects flow but is relatively constant. Local regulation occurs primarily through changes in arteriolar resistance.
whyIncorrect.b: Circulating neurotransmitters (hormones like epinephrine) affect systemic vascular resistance but are not the primary LOCAL regulators.
whyIncorrect.c: Cardiac output determines total systemic flow but not the distribution of flow to individual organs - that's determined locally.
whyIncorrect.d: Local neurotransmitters (sympathetic/parasympathetic) contribute to vascular tone but metabolic factors dominate local regulation in most tissues.

explanations.summary: Amino acids are completely reabsorbed in the proximal tubule via Na+-coupled secondary active transport.

whyCorrect.a: Amino acids are reabsorbed almost entirely (>99%) in the proximal tubule by Na+-dependent co-transporters on the apical membrane, similar to glucose reabsorption.

whyIncorrect.b: The thick ascending limb reabsorbs NaCl (via NKCC2), not amino acids. It's involved in concentrating urine, not organic solute reabsorption.
whyIncorrect.c: The distal tubule fine-tunes Na+, K+, Ca2+, and H+ balance but does not reabsorb amino acids.
whyIncorrect.d: The collecting duct regulates water (ADH), Na+ (aldosterone), and H+/K+ balance. Amino acid reabsorption is complete before filtrate reaches here.
whyIncorrect.e: Amino acids are reabsorbed ONLY in the proximal tubule. There is no significant amino acid transport in the distal tubule.

explanations.summary: Skeletal muscle arteriolar vasodilation occurs via beta-2 adrenergic receptors (epinephrine) and muscarinic receptors (endothelium-dependent NO release).

whyCorrect.c: Muscarinic (M3) receptors on endothelial cells stimulate NO release, causing vasodilation. Some species have direct sympathetic cholinergic vasodilator fibers to skeletal muscle.
whyCorrect.d: Beta-2 adrenergic receptors on vascular smooth muscle cause vasodilation via cAMP. Circulating epinephrine activates these receptors, dilating skeletal muscle vessels during exercise/stress.

whyIncorrect.a: Nicotinic receptors are found at neuromuscular junctions and autonomic ganglia, not on vascular smooth muscle. They don't directly affect vessel diameter.
whyIncorrect.b: Alpha-1 receptors cause vasoconstriction, not vasodilation. They are the main sympathetic vasoconstrictor receptors on blood vessels.
whyIncorrect.e: Beta-1 receptors are primarily in the heart (increase HR and contractility). They play minimal role in vascular smooth muscle tone.

explanations.summary: RAS activation stimulates aldosterone secretion (Na+ retention) and decreases urine output through enhanced Na+ and water reabsorption.

whyCorrect.d: Angiotensin II is the primary stimulus for aldosterone release from the adrenal zona glomerulosa. Aldosterone increases Na+ reabsorption in the distal nephron.
whyCorrect.e: RAS activation promotes Na+ and water retention through multiple mechanisms: direct AngII effects on proximal tubule, aldosterone effects on collecting duct, and ADH stimulation - all DECREASE urine output.

whyIncorrect.a: RAS activation INCREASES blood pressure through vasoconstriction (AngII) and volume expansion (aldosterone), not decreases it.
whyIncorrect.b: RAS DECREASES urine output by promoting Na+ and water retention, not increases it.
whyIncorrect.c: Angiotensin II STIMULATES thirst (via the subfornical organ), increasing fluid intake - not suppressing it.

explanations.topicReference: Topic 44/50: Long-term BP regulation and ECF volume

explanations.summary: Pulmonary artery systolic pressure is approximately 24 mmHg - the pulmonary circulation is a low-pressure system.

whyCorrect.f: Normal pulmonary artery pressures are approximately 24/9 mmHg (systolic/diastolic) with a mean of ~14 mmHg. This is about 1/5 of systemic arterial pressure.

whyIncorrect.a: 35 mmHg would indicate pulmonary hypertension. Normal PA systolic is ~24 mmHg.
whyIncorrect.b: 120 mmHg is the normal SYSTEMIC (aortic) systolic pressure, not pulmonary.
whyIncorrect.c: 80 mmHg is the normal systemic diastolic pressure. PA systolic is much lower (~24 mmHg).
whyIncorrect.d: 50 mmHg would represent significant pulmonary hypertension.
whyIncorrect.e: 0-6 mmHg is the range for central venous pressure (right atrial pressure), not pulmonary artery systolic.

explanations.summary: Long-term blood pressure is determined by renal regulation of body fluid volume through pressure diuresis and hormonal control of Na+ balance.

whyCorrect.c: The kidney is the dominant long-term BP regulator. Pressure diuresis/natriuresis and hormonal systems (RAS, aldosterone, ANP, ADH) adjust blood volume over hours to days, setting the long-term BP level.

whyIncorrect.a: The Cushing reflex is an emergency response to increased intracranial pressure - it's not involved in routine long-term BP regulation.
whyIncorrect.b: Direct vasoconstrictor effects of AVP and AngII affect SHORT-TERM resistance. Long-term BP depends on volume regulation, not sustained vasoconstriction.
whyIncorrect.d: Baroreceptor reflexes reset within 1-2 days and regulate SHORT-TERM BP variations. They cannot set the long-term BP level.
whyIncorrect.e: Chemoreceptor reflexes respond to blood gas changes (O2, CO2, pH) and primarily regulate respiration, not long-term BP.

explanations.summary: Veins act as blood reservoirs because of their large volume capacity - they hold about 60-70% of total blood volume.

whyCorrect.c: The venous system holds ~65% of total blood volume due to its high compliance and large total capacity. This makes veins ideal capacitance vessels that can mobilize blood when needed.

whyIncorrect.a: Veins ARE highly distensible (compliant) - this contributes to their reservoir function, not detracts from it.
whyIncorrect.b: Low oxygen saturation is irrelevant to the reservoir function. The ability to store blood depends on volume capacity, not oxygen content.
whyIncorrect.d: Vein walls DO contain smooth muscle, which allows venoconstriction to mobilize stored blood. Absence of muscle would prevent active mobilization.
whyIncorrect.e: Superficial location of some veins is irrelevant to their reservoir capacity. Both superficial and deep veins contribute to blood storage.
